content: this will be where the planning meeting takes place on 2022-03-11T10:00:00-05:00
Hi @T-compiler/meeting , its time for our quad-weekly planning meeting.
before we get started, are there any announcements that anyone wants to share? Feel free to jot them down while I go get the link ready. :)
Here are the unscheduled meeting proposals. We have six this cycle.
I think the two incr comp proposals could be merged
@Aaron Hill yeah, let me write them all down first concretely here so we all have the meeting names and links in front of us
I think backlog bonanza is probably one that we should periodically do or fill in when exceptionally lacking other topics

The meeting proposals are:

  • Exposing a versioned, semi-stable MIR interface compiler-team#498
  • Parallel compilation support strategy compiler-team#492
  • The future of Rust incremental compilation compiler-team#491
  • Discuss concrete ways of making incr. comp. more robust compiler-team#490
  • Meeting proposal: State of formal methods tools in Rust compiler-team#488
  • Compiler Feature Backlog Bonanza compiler-team#484

Jack Huey said:

I think backlog bonanza is probably one that we should periodically do or fill in when exceptionally lacking other topics

I'm trying to understand what you're suggesting here. Do you mean we should ensure that we cover it every cycle (untill the backlog is drained)? Or are you saying we should only dedicate a meeting to it when we don't have a bunch of other proposals?
between Discuss concrete ways of making incr. comp. more robust and The future of Rust incremental compilation I guess there's some precedence for one needing to happen before the other?
@Santiago Pastorino there's a suggestion that the two could be merged. Certainly if they're kept separate then I agree, they probably should then be ordered in some way
The reason for "future of incr comp" is the lack of robustness is the current implementation
Likewise, the "Exposing a versioned, semi-stable MIR interface" is in part motivated by formal methods work, which then ties into "State of formal methods tools in Rust"
I think we could have one meeting to discuss short-term and long-term solutions for incr comp
With the long-term being some form of rewrite
I'm inclined to agree with that: I.e., I don't think we should dedicate more than one meeting this cycle to incr-comp

pnkfelix said:

Jack Huey said:

I think backlog bonanza is probably one that we should periodically do or fill in when exceptionally lacking other topics

I'm trying to understand what you're suggesting here. Do you mean we should ensure that we cover it every cycle (untill the backlog is drained)? Or are you saying we should only dedicate a meeting to it when we don't have a bunch of other proposals?

Maybe that should have been an and. I don't think it necessarily needs to be every cycle. Maybe every couple months make sure we have one meeting. And then if we don't have a bunch of other proposals, that's a good time to make sure we sprinkle it in.
if we determine that we need another meeting, it can probably be part of the next cycle.
Let me ask a question: should we actually take a few minutes now to read over all of the text of the proposals?
fwiw, I don't think increasing incr. comp. robustness necessarily requires a re-write
At the very least, I think I want to double-check compiler-team#488 before I speak on how it relates to compiler-team#498
okay, well, I just read compiler-team#488, and I suspect that there is potential for significant overlap with compiler-team#498 there.
The formal methods overview will definitely inform the discussion of a stable MIR interface, I'd say
@mw do you agree that we could merge compiler-team#490 and compiler-team#491?
or do you think there's enough material solely for compiler-team#490 that trying to broaden to compiler-team#491 will just distract?
I don't know, both a rather vague at this point :)
I'm currently inclined to say we're going to merge both of the related pairs of proposals.
if nothing else, it will mean we'll (hopefully) have multiple people who are willing to collaborate on making the doc to drive each meeting.

If we take the merging route, then the proposals on the table really are:
The meeting proposals are:

  • Exposing a versioned, semi-stable MIR interface compiler-team#498 / State of formal methods tools in Rust compiler-team#488
  • Parallel compilation support strategy compiler-team#492
  • The future of Rust incremental compilation compiler-team#491 / Discuss concrete ways of making incr. comp. more robust compiler-team#490
  • Compiler Feature Backlog Bonanza compiler-team#484

I think discussing how we want to evolve/refine the overall design of incr comp is great but in order to evolve the overall design, we're going to need more stability and a better story for dealing with incr comp bugs than just disabling it. I would vote that we have a meeting focused on improving the stability of the feature before we have one to discuss future designs.
yes, getting more clarity on what the current problems even are seems like a good idea
otherwise, how do we tell if an alternative approach even solves current problems

okay. in any case, it sounds like a meeting is warranted, and the only question is whether merging the two incr-comp meetings is a good idea, or if the scope should be explicitly limited to just "the current problems & how to make it more robust"
I also think that, given the items listed, the lowest priority one is "parallel compilation support strategy" compiler-team#492
yes, that is a long-standing problem
A long-standing problem and one that people have to opt-into via specialized local builds
i.e. one that isn't going to affect current users
(apart from it being one of our main paths to making the compiler faster, which everyone of course cares about.)

Anyway, having said all that, for this cycle its looking like our real proposals are:

  • Exposing a versioned, semi-stable MIR interface compiler-team#498 / State of formal methods tools in Rust compiler-team#488
  • Discuss concrete ways of making incr. comp. more robust compiler-team#490
  • Compiler Feature Backlog Bonanza compiler-team#484
And the main question left is: how to schedule them
Is @Xavier Denis around?
(pinging because compiler-team#488 is their proposal)
I just PM'ed them
I confirmed that the person I'm in touch with for the Kani project, @Celina V. , is available for any of the three meeting slots.

and I think @bjorn3 is also a stakeholder there (due to cranelift, at least)
but while we wait to hear back from any of them...
I'm curious who wants to own compiler-team#490 "Discuss concrete ways of making incr. comp. more robust"
@Aaron Hill , I know you were putting forward the point up above that if we don't have a plan for its future, is it premature to be figuring out its stability path
My personal opinion is that I don't think we will be outright ripping out the incr-comp code anytime soon.
I agree
and therefore the stability questions will remain relevant for foreseeable future.
My thinking was that any future design should avoid the kind of pervasive issues we're having right now
so it might make sense to discuss them togther
:wave:
But I'm okay with keeping them as separate meetings if that's what other people want

pnkfelix said:

Celina V. my current inclination is to join them.

or at least, I think having an understanding of what different formal methods tools are doing will inform our plans for a MIR interface.
Yes, I agree. As long as we don't keep MIR interface restricted to the formal methods tool space.

I talked to @nikomatsakis for a while about this problem last night. The short answer is, they gave a thumbs up to putting in efforts here, and specifically said that while in MIR's original design they had thought that a single MIR design could support both static reasoning and support for compiler optimizations, @nikomatsakis now thinks that may have been a bit naive

Celina V. said:

Yes, I agree. As long as we don't keep MIR interface restricted to the formal methods tool space.

ah I see. That's a reasonable concern. I'll make sure to engage with other stakeholders, specifically @bjorn3
(I don't know whether "miri" falls into "formal methods" space or not, but its another obvious stakeholder.)

pnkfelix said:

I talked to nikomatsakis for a while about this problem last night. The short answer is, they gave a thumbs up to putting in efforts here, and specifically said that while in MIR's original design they had thought that a single MIR design could support both static reasoning and support for compiler optimizations, nikomatsakis now thinks that may have been a bit naive

(the good news about this insight is that it may lead us to specify one stable form of MIR to support static reasoning, and have a different, compiler internal MIR that is extended to support encoding the results of certain optimizations.)

oli said:

We will definitely be drafting a doc ahead of time
and I think in this case it will be a good idea for us to circulate that doc amongst the interested stakeholders before the meeting, if possible.
I'm curious to know what kind of information would be in one and not in the other form of MIR. But we can discuss that in the meeting. :)
I'm curious in how far can we provide a semi-stable MIR interface without making the entire compiler compile using stable. For example rustc_serialize uses specialization.
yeah we'll need to talk about that.
The compiler definitely is a good testing ground for nightly features, so we might not want to require stable for it

one distinction that is probably going to come up is: How much of this is trying to refactor components of the compiler to be themselves exposed as external crates, vs how much is "just bolt on new compiler features that can output a "new" stable format.
this is something that @Celina V. teased apart in an outline she was showing me
vs can the metadata serialization itself be moved to stable without moving the rest to stable.
right, exactly
anyway, I think we've settled on our dates and our doc owners, right?

Yeah, I'm kind of thinking the "stable MIR interface" is not just a versioning scheme on top of the internal rustc data structures which would require freezing their implementations but rather a well-defined serialization format.

I think we've covered everything we need to cover in our planning meeting. I want to thank everyone in @T-compiler/meeting for coming, as well as our domain experts who made time to show up and let us know their availability. Thanks y'all!
These meetings all look super interesting; I'm very much looking forward to them!
